posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91425814
It always depends, the perfect settings will change constantly based on what you are doing. Denoise depends on what scaler you're using too for best results but it'll usually be around .6-.7
CFG should always be as low as reasonably possible, the default 7 is usually okay for me.
Steps depend on your sampler, SDE Karras converges really fast and 20 is more than enough for it most of the time.
I mostly change the step count until I get a composition I like, I think it affects that most, don't think of it as something related to detail.
But you should just experiment a lot so that you understand what each lever and knob does for when you need to adjust it.

posts.com: how would i go about storing user uploaded images on an s3 with references to the owner of the image? i'm thinking i could either create an entry on an external database with a reference to the image and the user, or i could create a key in the s3 which has the userid as a prefix. what would be the ideal solution? most guides seem to refer to the first option but i never see any good explanation as to why this is more beneficial. in the future i will also need to add more attributes to the image but i was thinking i could add that as metadata to the s3 object rather than populating a db?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91417089
The ideal solution will depend on your use case and requirements, but generally speaking, the first option of having an entry in an external database with a reference to the image and the user is a more common approach.

One of the main benefits of using a database is that it provides a centralized location to store information about the images, such as image metadata, and allows for easier querying and indexing of the data. This makes it easier to search and retrieve information about the images and their owners, as well as to enforce access controls and data management policies.

Using an S3 key prefix with the user ID is an option, but it may not be as flexible or scalable as using a database. With this approach, you would need to write custom code to handle querying and indexing of the data, and it may be harder to enforce access controls and manage data over time.

That being said, storing metadata as S3 object metadata is a common practice, and can be a good solution for smaller datasets. If you expect to have a large number of images, you may need to consider using a database for better scalability and manageability.

Would require a linear search + reduce

const books = [
  { title: 'x', author: 'Sue' },
  { tile: 'y', author: 'Jack' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Jack' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Mary' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Sue' },
  { tile: 'z', author: 'Jack' },
];

// Sort by authors that have written the most books
const authorsByNumBooks = books.reduce(
  (acc, book) => {
    const numBooks = (acc[book.author] || 0) + 1;

    return {
      ...acc,
      [book.author]: numBooks,
      max: acc[acc.max] > numBooks ? acc.max : book.author,
    };
  },
  { max: '' }
);

const authorWithMostBooks = authorsByNumBooks.max;

thanks, just figured it out with lodash when you posted
const mostBlogs = (blogs) => {
  const authors = _.countBy(blogs, 'author');
  const authorCounts = _.map(authors, (val, key) => ({
    author: key,
    blogs: val
  }));

  const maxAuthor = _.max(authorCounts);
  return maxAuthor;
};

Okay, not an exact answer to my question, but since I wanted to declare global variables, this works for me:

index.js:
window.$variable = "My text"


App.js (or other component):
return (
  <h1>{windows.$variable}</h1>
);


Will return:
<h1>My text</h1>


Hope this helps someone else, at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91424415

It all depends on how you're rendering it.

const myvariable = `My
Text
Example
`;

const paragraphs = myvariable.split("\n").map((line) => {
  const node = document.createElement("p");
  node.innerText = line;
  return node;
});

// render the paragraphs
document.body.append(...paragraphs);

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91425709
80C in gaming with the stock cooler is high but not far outside of the expected range. Meaning it could be normal if your room temp is on the high side, your fan curve is relaxed, or your case is choked. It's well within spec so there's nothing to worry about from a safety standpoint. To see if you have a real problem you should run a stress test and observe the temperature and, importantly, clock speed. If it goes up to 90C+ and/or throttles near or below base clock then you have an actual issue that needs to be addressed. A new cooler should fix it. You might want to buy a proper cooler anyway for noise reasons. Even a $30 tower cooler will vastly outperform the box one.

>>91407372
>Does anyone know how to get it to deliver the lines in a specific way?
What I found yesterday, is that creating duplicates of the dataset, (ie, anonvoice1, anonvoice2) and actually having a specific dataset for a particular speech pattern, can help. And you can do this without gutting your original dataset, and if you stay on the same seed, you flick between them and see if it sounds any better or avoids the Britishness. I don't know how latents work, but there's no way they're getting 200mb of speech down to 10kb - hence, I think splitting it up and keeping strong emotions isolated might help.

The bigger problem I think, is that no matter what, the audiobooks bleed in and give everything an unsettling calm. itoddler probably talks like that, but models trained on speakers chosen for their clarity and lack of accent for kindlefags aren't going to be robust for memes. There's a hint of "I'm going to teach you how to meditate while you jog" in every inference.

I'm unironically impressed by how good tortoise does at replicating the male Imperial voice from Morrowind. The latent was built ~180 samples from Morrowind's datafiles, each 2-5 seconds in length:
using fast preset reading a copypasta (cant remember render time): https://voca.ro/130xBfm9ULiw
ultra fast preset, sneedpasta: https://voca.ro/12KaK9kDBEi2
ultra fast preset reading a book from Oblivion (took about 6 minutes to generate on a 4090 as I didn't want to wait an hour): https://vocaroo.com/14qgBk1iOjcX

Link to the latent + dataset: https://files.catbox.moe/s4il3l.zip

From what I can tell, deeper clear bass/baritone voices map better to male voices and are less likely to jump into random english girl mode. I would assume similar for higher pitched female voices. Voices that are more dynamic tend to break more.

What we need to do is replace GPT-2 in his model with a better, larger transformer model, gather a very large dataset--larger than his at 50,000 hours of English, and continue training it for an undisclosed period of time, until it begins to overfit and we can select the best model following the Chinchilla approach.

This is highly improbable to work with cash money. Likely we'd need to get hivemind working with decentralized training.
That way, the model can keep training while anons still have the willpower and bills to pay while not having to deal a questionable cash flow.

Youtube is easy enough with youtube-dl, but Spotify podcasts would probably be better, but I don't know of any way to scrape them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91421686
The data, wherever it comes from, also needs to be preprocessed.
Tortoise is known to fuck up immensely when given non-speech sounds.
This is because the training data does not, and realistically will not contain non-speech sound effects.
The source audio has to be cut down to a certain length, containing at most multiple sentences.

Then each clip needs to be transcripted. This step is critical, because the transcription process will decide how adaptable your model is to non-speech sounds, such as laughing or SNIIFFFFing

posts.com: When you create the account, you convert the password to sha256 (or some other hash, check if it's been cracked tho like md5) and when they login you convert their password to sha256 as well, and check the hashes instead of using plaintext, so if someone jacks your db they don't have everyone's login info. If it's just one server you'll be fine with php sessions, if it's a large scale project look into tokens. I'm sure you can find a PHP pdf somewhere to skim through, most of them will teach you exactly what you're looking for.

IT
>Plug in laptop
>Plug ethernet into router
>Install windows 11 pro by clicking through the options
>Download Notepad++
>Install WAMP
Frontend
>Make webpage in HTML
>CSS that highlights the buttons when you on:hover
>JavaScript that dynamically changes the welcome message every time you open the page
Backend
>Change the main file to index.php
>Create a txt file called "usercount.txt"
>Every time someone opens the page, the txt file is incremented
>Display at the top of the page
Database
>Create a folder labeled users
>Create login.php
>Make the username the filename and the contents the password
>Use sessions to track if a user is logged in, because there's NO way you'll scale to tokens
Deployment
>Login to HostGator or something
>Click the upload button
>Upload the whole htdocs folder without reviewing it
DevOps
>Write the login and password for your HostGator account on a sticky note
Version control
>Copy the htdocs folder to a flash drive and stick it under your pillow. Do this every week
Agile Scrum
>Every morning, look yourself in the mirror and talk to yourself with business jargon for an hour

posts.com:
How do I get battery stats like Androids?

Coming over from Android I’m used to being able to see which app has consumed exactly how much battery it’s drained since my last full charge to %100.

There’s two problems with iOS for me:
1. Inability to see battery usage since last full charge
2. Battery stat percentage for apps compare drainage against battery lost, rather than total battery available. So if I charge my phone to 100 and use safari until my battery is drained to 80, stats will show safari has used like 95ish% give or take (excluding background app usage) this percentage comes from comparing usage against battery lost rather than total available battery.

Do ex-Android users know what I’m talking about?

>>91415545
You know before ChatGPT was known, the rest of us were paying attention to GPT-3 which actually had the same capabilities but people were too dumb to notice. OpenAI's CEO was surprised by people being so shocked by it. It never surprised me much, in fact the original was more creative and RLHF brainwashing generally makes them more dull.
Anyway, back then there was a serious rush, commercial and freedom loving types to train it, so nowadays we have:
1. OPT-175 from facebook - have to ask for the weights but they give them. Their 60, 30, 20, 12B models have direct download links available. they are public! These are traind the same as GPT-3, on public dataset, not censored, all good base models.
2. YaLM from Yandex. 100B model, 25% eng, 75% russian. Direct download available.
3. BLOOM 176B, more curated dataset but performance may be subpar, it should still be quite usable though.
4. GLM-120B, 50 english/50 chinese model, very capable, high scoring. Weights are given to anyone that asks, people have played with it.
5. Many smaller models, Eleuther did some 20B I believe, a 6B, some other 10Bs exist, at some point even google released a 20B model

All of these are base models that haven't had any brainwashing applied.
You also have enthusiasts catering to coomers like Kobold which has finetuned models up to 30B on fiction and erotica.
Anyway, the problem is that you need to be serious about it and buy the appropriate acceleration hardware. Buying a few generation used stuff and backporting code to work with it would be fine for anyone dedicated. You'd have to pay a few thousands of dollars but you'd be set.
Of course you can just train anything in cloud too, at 10x the electricity price that you'd be paying yourself for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91415863
Also you don't even truly need to train a new one. Maybe if you wanted a pure dialogue model like chara.ai you could, but ChatGPT isn't even that, it's just their second iteration of GPT-3 finetuned a bit for dialogue, then supervised training for "safety" and instruction following, followed by some RLHF to build effective aversions toward some things. I do not think you'd get shut down if you crowdfunded, aside from the initial payment part, but you could just use cryptocurrency. Amazon, Google, etc do not care, and smaller players certainly don't care, people have trained a commercial GPT-3 clone by buying up cheap compute from various GPU renting platforms (like vast.ai). Coomers on /vg/ that are more rich just rent stuff on runpod and others to play with their tuned models, up to 60B sometimes, but that's obviously pricier to run.

>>91419742
So they have a 20b, a 30b, and a 6b, the one /g/ is playing with is a 6b finetune with a chat dataset, while the 20-30b ones are more general purpose fiction writing tunes.
Also lest you forget, NovelAI's 20b is also a finetune off the same GPT NeoX model, and the weights leaked along with the SD anime finetune, you might be able to find it in the second torrent (hopefully it's seeded), if you're prefer that to the open source finetune. Of course, if you're renting cloud it would be cheaper to just pay for NovelAI.

Your realistic choices may be between a smarter one like OPT-66B which is quite smart, but isn't fiction finetuned, or a 20 or 30B one that is less smart, but will be more directly tuned for coom. Personally I find that even normal GPT-3 (davinci and code-davinci-002) is excellent for coom purposes even untuned on any fiction, but ymmv.

if you get a job, here's some key tips

The switches aren't the best and it's ABS plastic that will eventually shine and lose some paint. Bluetooth is not the best, sometimes it won't just work right. Using it only wired personally. It's not programmable.

Still, for the price it's really nice. Backlighting, low profile, 75%, etc.

Get switches that actuate on click, or direct linears. The switches really aren't the best. Stabes are decent though.

Not many 75% low profile keyboards out there, so this is probably one of your best bets.

I'm pretty happy with it. 90% of my end-game already here. Just some minor improvements and I don't have to think about keyboards ever again.

Not OP but I'm curious why 2 cpu's using the same instruction sets are hard to emulate

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91417459
Because if you execute the opcodes directly on the CPU, it stops being emulation and becomes virtualization.
Further, while a (say) Pentium MMX has (largely) the same ISA, they have different instruction execution times, side-effects, errata, etc.

i don't see how you could gain anything trying to split the emulation of a single core cpu across multiple cores
if it was possible to gain anything that way, then we would have software/operating systems which accelerate single-threaded programs by using multiple cores
the problem is that each step requires the results of the previous step, and they have to be done in order, so there's really no room for splitting the work between independent cores

>this poster(s)
Our posts are ten seconds apart.
Critical thinking is important.

And if you really want the most cynical possible take:

>How many times do conspiracys pf this caliber have to be true before they stop being conspiracys?
That's not how conspiracies work.
If a few people are working in secret for a terrible but mutually profitable goal, then that's a credible conspiracy. If everybody is openly working for a terrible goal, then that's a broken system.
Look at it this way: if your hypothetical Illuminati all had heart attacks tomorrow, whatever schemes they're up to would end. If Facebook folded tomorrow, then another company would take their spot within a month.

>Its not even crazy to think that this is happening
It's not crazy, it's just lazy.
Google doesn't intrinsically give a fuck if you find the search results you want or not: They're a advertising company. They exist to turn adverts for other company's shit into clicks from you.
Assuming that the reason that they're doing something is because they're following a hidden agenda is absurd when the shit they're doing can far more easily be explained by profit and greed.

I'd agree if there wasn't a mountain of evidence proving otherwise.
Yes with every new media there was a wave of actual unironic luddites screaming about it being the end of the world. Books, music, radio, tv, video games, the internet. But time and time again we've seen studies wiping the floor with the bullshit that was said about each.
I've grown up between the hysteria of music is causing kids to sacrifice goats to Hitler and shoot up schools and video games causing kids to shoot up schools and rampage and rape and everything else.
Having lived before social media, before algorithm driven content, seeing its beginnings, its rise, its peak, its short decline and now its evolution I can tell you this is different. And it's not just me random internet schizo saying so. Study after study comes to the same conclusion, social media isn't healthy for humans no matter the age. It's causing and fuelling mental health issues, developmental issues, issues with self esteem, attention spans are shrinking, those aren't some hysterical luddites screeching at clouds and making shit up. It's hard, cold, verifiable data. What's now also very slowly coming to light is that Facebook et al. knew from the very beginning and worked to suppress that information because the implications would have been bad for business to say the least. And that's not a conspiracy theory that is conspiracy fact.
We're only now beginning to see serious studies into parasocial relationships, their effects especially on the still developing minds of children and if what we know about social media is anything to go by it's looking fucking grim.

Google defines it as

Here's the truth. They've unleashed weak AI en masse on many platforms. Part of it is interpretation of the query, ie instead of returning results based on specifics, it interprets what the user wants. So if you search 'volkswagen blah blah blah' it will interpret the user wanting to purchase a car, ideally a Volkswagen. So instead of information on the model, first and foremost it returns results that will lead to you purchasing a car, ie local dealerships, listings, etc. This is absolutely normal and to be expected, because ad services (read: 'search engines') are incentivized to make you spend your money. They don't make money when you read a wikipedia article, they make money when you go to their sponsors and spend your money. Another weak AI they have is an attempt to limit wrong-think. Type in anything political that happened and the first result is always a fact checker with a lazily (gpt)written article, or some 'expert' analysis by Dr Goldstein on why x y z is bad or good.
Tldr: the internet belongs to big corpo and their media/politico buddies. spend your money and consoom, don't think about the deboonks, just trust the experts

There is nothing inherent to it that prevents it, the problem is that there is no point in copy-pasting an existing GPL'd C utility and making it a GPL'd rust utility. You could argue "safety" ergo "it's rust", but that doesn't hold in real life because you need something to be """battle tested""" for use (as opposed to for copy-paste/stealing, in which case all that matters is if it has features. The irony is not lost on me, but I also have no power over it). On the other hand, if it's MIT licensed, the reason is right there: in the license. Importantly, if someone made a GPL-licensed rust utility and then someone 3 years later made the same but MIT licensed, nobody would use the GPL licensed one. Then the question becomes: why would someone waste effort remaking a GPL utility into MIT? The answer is: people are actually paid good money to do exactly that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91421277
MIT allows you to do anything you want so long as you keep the copyright header.
GPL forces you to share source code modifications you made to the software if you distribute it (but not if you merely run it on your own infrastructure). AGPL forces you to do the same even if your software only runs on your server, so long as it is providing the service to users. GPL and AGPL also require that the software preserves the freedom of users to read, share and modify the source. For example, UE4 and UE5 are open source, but they aren't GPL-compatible because they don't allow you to distribute the UE source code freely and such.

>>91425598
Every file on your computer contains code
You can edit this code freely
Said code will be read by a program that tries to access it for any reason, in this case its explorer.exe to generate the thumbnail and to collect the images data.
If the image contains malicious code, the program accessing the file could be susceptible to said malicious code.
Basically literally every file could be the host to a virus, its just exceptionally rare and hard to do.

Ruby died for two major reasons. The first, more forgivable reason, was the fact that it used to be insanely slow. Ruby is still somewhat slow, but 1.x was on a whole different level. It felt sluggish even even doing trivial tasks. Eventually it got better but by then, the language was on the downswing.
The second, sadder reason is webdev. Ruby ended up being flanderized as "the rails language" so its ecosystem ended up being 99% webshit. Combined with the fact that Rails devs were massive faggots (google "rails is a ghetto"), it was pretty much doomed from the get go.
A shame, since the language really has gotten better since it imploded in relevance, and is overall a rather tidy and fun language. It would have made an excellent Perl successor if it remained relevant.

>Open-Source DOES NOT mean LIBRE
Libre meaning free as in freedom--being able to manipulate the code and freely creates forks of it if you want without legal ramifications--not free as in Instagram/Facebook/Twitter.

There are tons of projects that use the "Free" + "Open-Source" model to trick users into thinking that's it's something that it is technically not. Free and Open-Source has a specific notion to it and we tend to think of it like the typical Linux software we come across but in fact they are Free and Open-Source while technically not being Libre.

#include <array>
#include <vector>
#include <iostream>
template<size_t t>
constexpr auto f = [] <template<typename, size_t> typename T, typename U, size_t size> (T<U, size> a, std::same_as<T<U, size>> auto ... b) consteval {
    static_assert(size > 0);
    auto v = std::vector<U>{};
    for (int i = 0; i < size; i++)
    {
        v.push_back(a[i]),(v.push_back(b[i]), ...);
    }
    if constexpr(!t)
    {
        return v.size();
    }
    else
    {
        auto result = std::array<U, t>{};
        std::copy(begin(v), end(v), begin(result));
        return result;
    }
};
int main()
{
    constexpr std::array<int, 3> i{1, 2, 3};
    constexpr std::array<int, 3> j{1, 2, 3};
    constexpr std::array<int, 3> k{1, 2, 3};
    constexpr auto k2 = f<f<0>(i, j, k)>(i, j, k);
    for (auto&& i : k2)
    {
        std::cout << i;
    }
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91421474
The triumvirate of simple syntaxes is lisp, forth and smalltalk.
The rarely talked about other segment is so-called command languages, like early fortran or more or less BASIC: the first thing on any line is a command, anything else is "params" (for example DO i = i + 1 or FOR i FROM 1 UPTO 10). Assembly languages typically count in this category as well.
After that you have Wirthian languages. They will look more familiar and algol-like (i.e. like C), but are designed to be very simple and clean despite the familiarity. Whether you like that syntax is another matter. These include oberon, pascal, and modula-2.
Do you consider ML-family languages to be small in that regard? SML/NJ could still be a good reference there if so.

constexpr auto f = [] <template<typename, std::size_t> typename T, typename U, std::size_t N> (T<U, N> a, std::same_as<T<U, N>> auto ... b) consteval {
    static_assert(N > 0);
    std::vector<U> v;
    for (int i = 0; i < N; i++)
    {
        v.push_back(a[i]);
        (v.push_back(b[i]), ...);
    }
    std::array<U, N * (sizeof...(b) + 1)> result;
    std::copy(std::begin(v), std::end(v), std::begin(result));
    return result;
};

>>91421675
I went through that phase, too. In the end I gave up on the idea and settled for an iterated bootstrap scheme (you write a simple version of your language and pass it host functions, then you rewrite those host functions into machine code using your language, then you add increasing amounts of functionality... this also allows you to start with a trivial parser and to complexity it through the boostraps). It does leave a bitter taste in the mouth but with all the time I spent on this, that's the best I could do. My conclusion is that chuck moore is a true genius for having come up with forth, and that it cannot be improved whatsoever, which is why it still has stack acrobatics that hurt my personal use.

There are no other mindfuck languages once you're past smalltalk, lisp and forth except in the esolang scene. Things like nemerle can fuck with you in many ways, as can parallel languages and flowchart languages, but they also happen to be ludicrously complex in the backend, and sometimes also in the frontend by partial necessity.

Linked lists are always easy to implement. Stack (e.g. alloca) still limits you to stack size cutoff from the OS and good luck maintaining a few of those between calls. That said, since you name alloca, you shouldn't have a problem using realloc, so vectors should not be a problem. In asm you just write a simple malloc implementation: 1- check brk with current ptr 2- move the brk if needed, otherwise just push the pointer to the new size and return the old start. Done. That's a push allocator, which is going to be good enough until you have a full language for which to implement a proper malloc in.
For control flow structures, the best universal one is probably pattern matching. Failing that you can just use labels (i.e. no structure). Otherwise you're stuck with a loop and a conditional of any kind (doesn't really make much difference which, if is easy to implement and cond can be somewhat harder, though not much).

I got interested in Lisp about 15 years ago. I tried Common Lisp first, reading both ANSI Common Lisp (Graham) and Paradigms of AI Programming (Norvig). CL never felt natural to me. I kept getting annoyed by seemingly minor details like string formatting, awkwardness of hash tables and the split namespace. I also didn't like the default debugger that CLers all claim they can't live without. For every live-edit I made, there would be a dozen times it was extra hassle to cancel out of.

I tried Clojure and loved it. I read Programming Clojure (1st edition by Stuart Halloway. Currently it's on 3rd edition and the main author is Alex Miller). A lot of things just seemed to click. I liked the immutable data structures including the syntax for vectors and maps. There was some friction dealing with Java and the JVM since I wasn't a Java programmer, but I figured learning that kind of thing would be more career-useful than CL.

His writing style is clear and easy to read.
Note also that both books were written and published well before Graham become an eceleb and even before he founded Viaweb.

>>91414548
>>91414615
I checked and yeah looks like you're right. for some reason directory-files is CS while directory-files-recursively is CI. that's inconsistent and weird, the developers should change it

but there's a simpler way to solve your problem. the fourth argument to directory-files-recursively is a function that determines if a subdirectory should be searched. if you pass it a lambda that always returns nil, it will only search the given directory:
(directory-files-recursively "~/.emacs.d" "^.*\\.el$" nil (lambda (x) nil))


I think this will do what you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91414995
Python:
[i + 10 for i in range(0, 10) if i % 2 == 0]
Lisp:
(loop for i from 0 to 9 when (evenp i) collect (+ i 10))

The difference is that you can do 10 times more stuff in lisp loop, such as instantiate and initialize variables, and on and on. Loop is a list comprehension machine.

For instance, if i wanted to do
[i + 10 for i in r=range(0,10)...] I couldn't, because you can't in Python
You'd have to do:
r = [10, 20, 5, 2]
[i+10 for i in r...]

In lisp, its
(loop with r = '(10 20 5 2) ...)

This is just a trivial example, but the possibilities are so much more with loop than with a list comprehension.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91416638
You should probably stick to python until you understand why you might need more.

Also, loop iterates over all the stuff.
Lists:
(loop for i in '(0 1 2) ...)
Cons cells:
(loop for i on '(0 1 2) ...)
vectors:
(loop for i across #(0 1 2). ..)
keys and values of hash tables:
(loop for i being the hash-key of your-hash ...)
(loop for i being the hash-value of your-hash ...)
(loop for i being the hash-key using (hash-value j) of your-hash ...)

It can also loop over symbols in a package.
If you aren't using loop, you're doing it wrong.

>>91416638
Not that guy, but...
>Also also, is there any _point_ to learning CL aside from it being interesting to learn?
If you know it, SBCL is a very good runtime. You can get performant code that runs on a variety of platforms. Common Lisp has a standard and is stable so what you learn can be expected to last for awhile.
>I'm a beginner in python too so would it be unwise to spend time on cl projects and shit instead of python projects from a career perspective?
This is hard to say. In one respect, learning Python is just not very hard and the more experience you have with CL the easier it will be to pick up Python.
>Or would people look at me and go "wew, he learnt CL so he must genuinely be interested in programming"?
Common Lisp is unlikely to make much difference on a resume all by itself. The devil is in the details. If you come off like a hobbyist who never really did anything more than tinker around with toy projects, CL may do as much harm as good. But if you look like you have tackled some serious projects, it will probably be assumed you can transition to Python/Javascript/PHP. Personally, I would recommend also learning a traditional imperative language with static typing (eg Go).

>Tortoise TTS stack: Learn what it does. Suggest improvements. Compare it to 11 labs.
1) Autoregressive transformer stack predicts discrete speech "tokens" given a text prompt. (Like DALLE using GPT but with speech)
2) CLIP model judges autoregressive transformer outputs against the text ranking the most probable.
3) Speech tokens are decoded into a low-quality MEL spectrogram using a VQVAE.
4) UNet diffusion model decodes VQVAE output into raw audio wav file using openAI ImprovedDiffusion.
>Tortoise is basically OpenAI's DALLE, applied to speech data.

>What can you do: Look for code improvements in these forks, report back

NEWS: NEW GOOGLE PAPER JUST PUBLISHED: SpearTTS
https://arxiv.org/pdf/2302.03540.pdf
>is the end result of their earlier research? https://arxiv.org/pdf/1806.04558.pdf

Speak, Read and Prompt: High-Fidelity Text-to-Speech with Minimal Supervision
We introduce SPEAR-TTS, a multi-speaker text-to-speech (TTS) system that can be trained with minimal supervision. By combining two types of discrete speech representations, we cast TTS as a composition of two sequence-to-sequence tasks: from text to high-level semantic tokens (akin to "reading") and from semantic tokens to low-level acoustic tokens ("speaking"). Decoupling these two tasks enables training of the "speaking" module using abundant audio-only data, and unlocks the highly efficient combination of pretraining and backtranslation to reduce the need for parallel data when training the "reading" component. To control the speaker identity, we adopt example prompting, which allows SPEAR-TTS to generalize to unseen speakers using only a short sample of 3 seconds, without any explicit speaker representation or speaker-id labels. Our experiments demonstrate that SPEAR-TTS achieves a character error rate that is competitive with state-of-the-art methods using only 15 minutes of parallel data, while matching ground-truth speech in terms of naturalness and acoustic quality, as measured in subjective tests.

>Fault-tolerant backpropagation: forward and backward passes succeed even if some nodes are unresponsive or take too long to respond.
>Decentralized parameter averaging: iteratively aggregate updates from multiple workers without the need to synchronize across the entire network

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91411461
This is how anons are doing stable diffusion collaborative training. It would be good to discuss the best collaborative AI training methods as many point out anons don't have individual resource
https://github.com/chavinlo/distributed-diffusion
>SAIL discord
https://discord.gg/8Sh2T6gjd2
>How they do P2P swarm training
1. Dataset
Currently code expect dataset to be in form of image jpg,jpeg,webp,png and accompanying json file that contains tags i.e danbooru dataset. Currently it's hardcoded and will be used as example one for that guide.
Sqlite db is stored in repo as index of files, and files served from linode bucket in pairs, there is check in code to discard non paired images. During training, both image and json are fetched, and from json extracted only description tags and saved as txt file alongside image in workplace directory.
2. Mother node
Currently it expects to have GPU and will be part of the swarm. For distributed training you also need configuration in next step.
3. Relay mode
Next step is to set up relay configuration in UI, that will allow your node to serve config endpoint to peers - from wich they will be able to grab config, for that purprose I.E port are used. So if you behind NAT it makes sense to portforward port 80 to your internal I.E port, TCP ports are used for DHT connections so as well needed to be portforwarded, and your public ip will be used as DHT server, so that ip (or domain name ) you can spread among peers so they would be able to join swarm.
If you are NOT behind NAT, put matching pairs of ports here, so advertised and listened ports are matched and that will do the trick.
4. Training
After configuration and start of training, there will be main events after 1200 seconds i.e 20 minutes
Optimizer and Averager events should start and peers will exchange trained weights - that should lead to decrease in loss.
Due to geography and network speeds, and size of weights that part may be tricky so keep an eye on that.
5. Wait

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
VITS two stage training
>https://arxiv.org/pdf/2106.06103.pdf
>Conditional Variational Autoencoder with Adversarial Learning for End-to-End Text-to-Speech
Several recent end-to-end text-to-speech (TTS) models enabling single-stage training and parallel sampling have been proposed, but their sample quality does not match that of two-stage TTS systems. In this work, we present a parallel end-to-end TTS method that generates more natural sounding audio than current two-stage models. Our method adopts variational inference augmented with normalizing flows and an adversarial training process, which improves the expressive power of generative modeling. We also propose a stochastic duration predictor to synthesize speech with diverse rhythms from input text. With the uncertainty modeling over latent variables and the stochastic duration predictor, our method expresses the natural one-to-many relationship in which a text input can be spoken in multiple ways with different pitches and rhythms. A subjective human evaluation (mean opinion score, or MOS) on the LJ Speech, a single speaker dataset, shows that our method outperforms the best publicly available TTS systems and achieves a MOS comparable to ground truth.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm unironically impressed by how good tortoise does at replicating the male Imperial voice from Morrowind. The latent was built ~180 samples from Morrowind's datafiles, each 2-5 seconds in length:
using fast preset reading a copypasta (cant remember render time): https://voca.ro/130xBfm9ULiw (embed)
ultra fast preset, sneedpasta: https://voca.ro/12KaK9kDBEi2 (embed)
ultra fast preset reading a book from Oblivion (took about 6 minutes to generate on a 4090 as I didn't want to wait an hour): https://vocaroo.com/14qgBk1iOjcX (embed)

Link to the latent + dataset: https://files.catbox.moe/s4il3l.zip

From what I can tell, deeper clear bass/baritone voices map better to male voices and are less likely to jump into random english girl mode. I would assume similar for higher pitched female voices. Voices that are more dynamic tend to break more.

>>91425595
this should get you started on tortoise
https://huggingface.co/jbetker/tortoise-tts-v2
Adding a new voice
To add new voices to Tortoise, you will need to do the following:
Gather audio clips of your speaker(s). Good sources are YouTube interviews (you can use youtube-dl to fetch the audio), audiobooks or podcasts. Guidelines for good clips are in the next section.
Cut your clips into ~10 second segments. You want at least 3 clips. More is better, but I only experimented with up to 5 in my testing.
Save the clips as a WAV file with floating point format and a 22,050 sample rate.
Create a subdirectory in voices/
Put your clips in that subdirectory.
Run tortoise utilities with --voice=<your_subdirectory_name>.

Sway starts XWayland on demand so you have two options:
1)
Run 
swaymsg exec program-you-want-to-start

xwayland force
in your Sway config which will always start XWayland even if it's not needed right now.

posts.com:
Users of all levels welcome. Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>Which W10 version should I install?
Home/Pro: No, comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps.
Education/Workstation/Enterprise: Yes, but comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only): Yes, but comes with Win32 system utils, limited system apps like Settings and Notification area, no MS Store. If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other versions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS can trip your AV and deactivate. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something. If you know what you're doing:

>As a client–server protocol, SMB requires a server service (LanmanServer) and a client service (LanmanWorkstation). Every Windows computer, whether it is running a server OS (like Server 2016 or Server 2019) or a client OS (like Windows 10 or Windows 11), has both the LanmanServer and LanmanWorkstation services. You can check the status of both services using the Get-Service Lanman* PowerShell command.
https://4sysops.com/archives/the-smb-protocol-all-you-need-to-know/

posts.name: Faggot OP
posts.com:
>>91418368
Strictly speaking, you don't need LanmanServer to access a network drive (and it's in fact turned off on a lot of enterprise machines for this reason).
You'd probably want the Function Discovery services too, because they populate the Network Neighbourhood icon, otherwise you're stuck with having to type \\Server\Share into the Map Network Drive dialog, File Explorer's address bar, etc. - but like the Server service, they aren't actually required.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91422830
>Harddisk4
Was set up with a tool you specifically told that you would never boot from the drive, so you didn't get an ESP at all.
>Harddisk5
Was set up under either Vista or 7 disk management. They used a 100MB ESP - later versions of Windows use progressively larger default ESP sizes, but are thus far always divisible by 100.
>Harddisk6
Was set up with a possibly Linux/FOSSshit partitioning tool, as they seem to like powers of 2 - so you get system partition sizes like 128MB or 512MB instead of 100MB or 500MB.
>If my partition tables get wiped by accident would the backup headers contain all the info to still let me mount the volumes
The backup GPT is stored in the last few sectors of a drive, where they're safe from dskwipe, dd etc. unless you let them run to completion. In practice though, when you start from absolute sector 0 and start blasting data, you don't generally stop when you hit the first partition, and there's some pretty important data stored in the early sectors of partitions.
While both GPT (as mentioned) and NTFS back up their important data elsewhere, to my knowledge, nothing uses them automatically - you'll need some sort of tool to recover the backup GPT or $MFTMir.

I've developed websites since the early 2000s and it's become hell. The average user in 2023 demands too much.

I'm not even gonna talk about how much entertainment and socializing the user wants before he agrees to use the site. First there's how nervous zoomers are about security. This is the first generation of Internet users that are neurotic about cyber security, despite the fact that they exclusively use Big Tech sites and completely ignore world-class data theft.

I just had a guy screech at my site because I host it under a pseudonym.
>"The admin is a literal who. Most likely an IP grabber"
I get these "most likely x" type of insults often and it should be illegal to give other users the impression that my site does that when there's no proof of it. Just hinting at that can tank my site, because people have zero media criticism. If someone says my site is an IP grabber, the word will spread and soon there are news articles being made about it. In my 20 years of webdevving I have not found any reason to doxx myself just for making free websites and software. The zoomer generation disagrees. They want "TRuSt". And this is coming from posters who themselves will go to any lengths to stay anonymous.

And yeah we're talking about free services here. I give stuff for free and get nothing back. I've currently hosted a content platform out of my own pocket for a year without getting a single user. It's just that hard these days, folks. I've seriously considered getting another profession, like writing a book or something. And yeah, I'll do that under a pseudonym too, fucker. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>you guys
Don't put words in my mouth.
>Technological reasons we're not there yet.
Shit's hard.
Recognizing things via camera and radar is pretty much figured out, so maintaining distance from a predictable car ahead, recognizing traffic signs and markings and obeying them, maintaining speed, determining when it's safe to merge, that sort of thing.
The catch is that a hypothetical self-driving car shares the road with human drivers, and as any driver will tell you it's not a sterile equation, quite often you have to be dirty or consider things that are outside the law.
So only a human driver can recognize that someone is a jackass and you best not share a lane with them, or decide to assertively force yourself into a merge in traffic, or thinks ahead when it comes to what you see in the distance, or deal with ambiguous situations like dirt roads, busted traffic lights or faded markings on thr road.
The way to get a car to react to something immediate is at a relatively advanced stage, but it's far from everything needed to make a driver.

Theoretically if we outlawed human drivers entirely the path to autonomous vehicles would be much shorter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Self-driving down empty roads is very achievable right now. Roads being used by pedestrians and human drivers are much more difficult as they require reliable prediction of human behaviour. This was the what they hadn't considered when Uber and Elon gambled on self-drive being imminent.

posts.com:
How do I get the most battery lifespan out of my new S23 Ultra? I'm moving to it from my good old Note10+ which after its 4 years had a very degraded battery capacity, and now I'm paranoid about that.

Correct me if I'm wrong:
> Don't keep it higher than 85% for too long
> Charge it before it reaches less than 15% or so
> Don't use fast charge, as slower the charge, less heat, so it's better.

Is wireless charging better than wired for this? Is wireless bad for the battery? Non-fast wireless doesn't seem to produce too much heat, and since it takes literally 4 hours (not a problem if charging overnight), I have the feeling it should be easier on the battery since the "load is injected" less intensely and spread out over a longer time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91413513
you basically got it right. charge it slowly and avoid being in highly charged or discharged state. you're better off using a wired charger instead of a wireless one at the same wattage (eg a 5w wired instead of a 5w wireless). other than that, don't roast your phone in the summer sun and try not to use it while the thing's charging for heat reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91413513
I think OneUI has the option to restrict charging to 85% but It will still behave like ordinary charging. Exynos kernels had the ability to disconnect the charger and run purely off external power (enabled with battery_slate_mode in /sys/class/power_supply/battery) for a long time (my Note 4 has it) but it was never exposed to the user in any way and remains unused to this day.
I'd say that heat isn't such a big deal anymore, the charging circuitry/driver should slow down when things get too hot. Charging past 4.2V(~85%) shortens the battery's lifespan more than fast charging.

>>91412442
I think the 13 is slightly fatter and heavier, but you get a slightly more battery time, both in capacity and operating time. Combined with the more efficient chipset, it adds up to being worth the price of admission at least for me.

Gsmarena did the same mixed method testing on both and came up with 68h for the 12 and 75h on the 13. This is low compared to Androids with monstrous battery sizes, but still a significant improvement.


Attached is my current weekly stats, showing the amount of discharge for a day along with how much usage was obtained. I don’t use my phone too much but it certainly exceeds my needs. Seems like AltStore was running in the background for a bit and my flashlight was left on, which adds a lot of screen off usage.

I do find that iPhones tend to have excellent standby time at the cost of background applications which are limited. I get broadly similar battery life across various OSs and devices, so your usage is probably more important.

So I'm not a HiFi guy but I think I could use some help from you guys, especially because my requirements are a bit specific.

>Tldr:
I'm looking for an DAC and Amp (or combo) that is reliable, accepts USB, has an 1/4inch jack output, only needs small wall warts and can drive the 300 ohms of an Sennheiser HD 650. Bonus points if there's also Bluetooth/Wifi support


>The full story
I got the 650 primarily for my digital piano so I can play in silence. I know the 650 also has a 0.14 jack cable, but the piano only accepts 1/4 plugs which is why I want to keep that for all other devices.

On my desk, keyboard, mouse, webcam and USB mic all connect to a single USB hub, which I then plug into my work laptop, home laptop or desktop PC depending on what device I want to use. (Still looking for a good USB Switch)

Sound has been a problem, USB dongles don't work, add noise or are too weak to drive the 650. I solved that by only using the HD 650 on my desktop (the realtek chip is surprisingly good) and connect to my laptops with a cheap bluetooth headset instead.

If I want to add Headphones to my setup, I need a DAC/Amp that accepts USB so I can just plug it in the Hub.

I looked into that Magi/Modi from Shiit everybody recommends, but the wall warts are too big for my power strip. I think their Asgard with USB extension card is what I'm looking for, but it's quite expensive, and at this price, I'd have additional features like Bluetooth or WiFi, and other vendors to compare them to

>>91421327
How much content is there for it? 5.1 has been around since the 1970s yet virtually all music is still mixed in stereo. Assuming what you're listening to has the metadata to support it, it's still just essentially making a two channel binaural recording when played through IEMs which isn't customized to the individual and 3D sound as if you were truly in the room is not possible regardless of the marketing wank.

Forget the amount of channels, the future of immersive sound will utilize head tracking and individualized head-related transfer functions. There are primitive attempts at this that use photos of the pinna to try to calculate it but it's still early days and it can't exactly account for ear canal shape so who knows how close it can get. Anyway this topic is a dead horse at this point and I don't want this thread devolve into "soundstage" shit flinging.

posts.com: For that idiot who was saying inverted polarity is minimum phase and that having no excess group delay means the system is minimum phase.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91425221
Not the anon you were arguing with, but Rene is actually contradicting himself in the video. Excess phase doesn't strictly mean a system is not minimum phase. The definition of minimum phase system is that the system and its inverse are causal and stable - and he does mention it in the video. Transfer function required to undo flipped polarity is causal and stable. Which he also does mention in the video and he doesn't consider polarity flip a problem https://youtube.com/watch?v=iBPTvMgRBe0&t=1h18m30s. Yet he calls polarity flip not minimum phase in his overview. A contradiction. But none of this really matters due to the fact that a system doesn't need to be minimum phase to have no phase and magnitude distortions, it just needs to be linear phase(constant delay), sound traveling from the driver to the eardrum is already not minimum phase.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91425546
I agree that the semantics of it are besides the point and that inverted polarity can be viewed as a special case since its inverse is causal and stable when the transducer is viewed as a system. These topics are defined rather unclearly and there is no clear-cut answer in the textbooks. Simply saying that there is high excess phase and that the phase response does not follow the predicted minimum phase response per the Hilbert transform would be more technically correct.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91413430
>rust programmers tend to use arrays as heap replacement, because using heap in rust is ugly, slow and inefficient, essentially replacing memory pointers with array indices.
This is not true. Rust's heap is no slower than other system programming languages. Box is no slower than unique_ptr and Rc is no slower than shared_ptr(it's even faster because it doesn't have to be atomic).
Using array indices is a valid practice that is used commonly in many algorithms and data structures, but it is not a replacement for memory pointers in any way. It's completely different approach. And it doesn't make it any faster than using pointers, the exact opposite is true.

>here is just one example
>https://rust-leipzig.github.io/architecture/2016/12/20/idiomatic-trees-in-rust/
It's clear this article was written by someone who doesn't know what he is talking about.
The whole premise boils down to:
>the thing is that this would kill every benefit from the borrow checker and could lead into the same pitfalls like in other languages.
Which is completely wrong for two reasons.
1) Benefits of Rust comes from strict safety guarantees and expressive type system that allows for embedding all sorts of invariants in it. It was never about writing everything without unsafe, it's all about writing safe abstractions over unsafe code so you can minimize potential surface of errors and write probably safe code. You can have all of that and still use pointers.
2) literally no one does that. You will not find this kind of code nowhere in stdlib nor in any popular container library. Containers are implemented using pointers and unsafe because it is the best practice and most effective method.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A small sized AI program with a large buffer tends to do the job pretty well.
But a large sized AI program with a small buffer tends to create erratic results with worse efficiency.
And this makes sense, because a smaller program is less likely to be lead astray from the start.

The problem is, bugs can be introduced externally (which is why GC has become a big thing no matter the time you use it) which can throw off small programs that may not be able to throw off the real bad perturbations out there.
A larger program may be able to harden itself against such bugs, but at the cost of simple efficiency. Further more, while the external bugs are better managed perhaps, the internal bugs and dissonance starts to become more of an issue.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91414979
>But traits can provide for implementations for types they do not define.
They can't. You can't define a trait that will just add methods to some type.
If you want to implement some trait for some type you need to implement using impl block, just like when you add methods to type. Instead of impl Type you use impl Trait for Type.

>It's confusing a type can be defined in 1 package, and then have its behavior modified by another.
Rust coherence rules do not allow some crate to implement an external trait to an external type. A crate can only implement trait to an external type if that trait was declared in this crate. And then it doesn't just append methods to that type universally, if you want to use these new methods on this type, you need in import that trait to your module.

It really isn't an issue in practice.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91415107
>They can't.
They can.

>Rust coherence rules do not allow some crate to implement an external trait to an external type
That's off-topic. This code shows the problem:

mod mymod {
    pub trait MyTrait {
        fn say_hi(&self);
    }

    impl MyTrait for i32 {
        fn say_hi(&self) {
            println!("hello world");
        }
    }

}

mod mym0d {
    pub trait MyTrait {
        fn say_hi(&self);
    }

    impl MyTrait for i32 {
        fn say_hi(&self) {
            println!("hola mundo");
        }
    }
}

//use mymod::MyTrait;
use mym0d::MyTrait;

fn main() {
    let x = 42;
    // You can't look at this line and know what method is being called.
    x.say_hi();
}


This is a horrible design decision. Readers simply cannot manage this context. It's an ugly choice.

>It really isn't an issue in practice.
It's been an issue for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've spent the last week playing with ChatGPT. I don't really like just chatting with it, because it just comes across to me as an endless platitude generator.

What has been a mixed bag is getting it to write programming code.

it can make really small simple things well. I can even give it ideas that are outside of its suggestions to gain new abilities to complete a goal.

It just gets so messed up if I ask it for anything too ambitious. And by too ambitious, I mean barely better than simple. When asking it to make a small fix to code that I noticed, it will take liberties and drop wide swaths of functionality that it took me an hour to drill into it.

The only real path to anything complex, is to avoid asking it for code for a long time. Just make a long plan, and walk through the logic of getting something done and the flow of events. If it's in the right mood, it will keep to the script and just let me follow a natural progression to lead it to progress. Once everything looks right, i can ask it for hypothetical function names, and then follow that by one-by-one asking it for examples of each function.

It's a fun toy. I don't see it taking anyone's programming job. I do love that I can ask it for examples and syntax.

I tend to find you can reason with it to break out as well.

I was once trying to get it to output something illegal and it kept giving me the same I cannot do that response.

I then pointed out the hypodermic needle model was discredited years ago and is no longer taken seriously.
I then assured it that I was not personally going to do anything bad with the information, and just because it shows me, it does not mean I will act on it. The automatic assumption I would do the things it shows me is as floored as the hypodermic needle model.

ChatGPT then apologise for making that assumption, agreed with me that the hypodermic needle model was indeed found flawed, and that human interaction with media was a lot more complex than previously thought. >>91409522
I’ll provide some of my own personal enlightenment regarding this… obviously kicks are important, and the idea is ‘let me narrow down my kick samples to the more optimal versions so I’m not sifting through 500 samples”. But the reality is there is really only a finite number of kick styles people try to emulate when they make “mega kick sample packs” and 95% of them are emulating drum machines of the era where a specific genre debuted. Get the original kick samples from a 909, 808, 707, kawai r, Roland r series, Yamaha rx series, DMX, and linndrum; then you will have all of the types of kicks the sample-pack makers start from. Imo sculpting these kicks to fit into your mix will be a lot easier than searching through someone else’s pre-processed versions of them in hopes they were processed in a way to fit in your mix.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91413718
Making drum sounds doesn't necessarily mean using exclusively synthesis.
Layering samples and synths as needed is the standard for creating sounds.
You can layer real-world recorded snares with synthesized layers (it's common to have a recorded snare for the noise and a synth for the body), or layering foley samples to give them a slightly more interesting flavor can give you some pretty good results.
A big advantage is that you can make sure that every layer is tuned to the right note/s that make sense in the context of the track, without having to re-pitch a complete sample and changing its character.

And sure, some of the one-shots available online can sound much better than the best ones I can make, but so do the samples and presets (and MIDIs lol) for basses, leads, FX, pads, etc.
I make my own drums for the same reasons I make my own version of everything else. The added control and the fact that they're mine and sound like me.
Everyone has a threshold for what matters that they make it themselves and what doesn't. For me (because of how I approach music and the type of music I make itself) drums completely clear that threshold, but everyone is different and as much as we shitpost about sampling being cheating, it's perfectly valid to use samples if you care about the end result more than whatever makes someone want to go DIY.

TL;DR: There are advantages and disadvantages to every approach. Choose what's right for you.

>>91413678
I think it really does come down to what your are personally trying to achieve. If you have no intention of being faithful to a genre, there’s no reason to uphold some drum samples that are historically attached to a genre. But at the same time, knowing the drum machines that were used for specific genres does give you the ability to ‘tip you hat” to your influences in an authentic way. Plus there are electronic music genres that are defined specifically by the use of sampled drums vs synthesized drums (eg jungle vs dnb, breakbeat vs electro)

>>91397046
It wasn't RDP/Clipboard stuff, but yeah, there was a CVE where you could trigger a very specific overflow in the crypto driver exposed by windows to the sandbox that would let you crash the system. No privacy threat or integrity threat though, just potential for data corruption due to unexpected shutdown.

The CVE you linked has nothing to do with Sandbox though. 2019-0887, long patched by now, could let an attacker execute code on your PC remotely if you connected to their compromised RDP machine. Given that RDP already gives you a ton of control over the host machine, it's not actually much of an escalation. Really just a way to run the code without being obvious to the RDP host. It doesn't let you do anything that you couldn't otherwise do, just gave you extra stealth.

>>91396427
This is a very bad advice, if you are willing to run viruses on a vm you better limit the scope of the vm access to the cpu, mouse, ram, etc, there are viruses that could fry your devices by exceeding voltage limits, also if the vm has internet or network access to your modem or router it could be loaded with vulnerability finders and try to change root configuration of your devices, simply by scanning adjacent connected networks, specially if people don't configure a guest network and block the ability from each device to ping each other, in short, using a vm to run viruses could be as dangerous as running them in your host machine, the only kind of mitigation is if you can the windows vm inside a Linux host, but still you'd have networking vulnerabilities, to be care with that advice man

running a DC++ hub for your neighborhood edition

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your tech skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

>>91379030
I assume you're talking about using containers built from Docker images vs installing everything next to each other on the same machine. Containerization brings some benefits:
>isolation of processes inside containers from other containers and from host
>higher portability (ties with previous point - as long as host kernel is relatively recent, you can run e.g. libc compiled software in the container even if host OS is Alpine with musl)
>the setup is self documenting and declarative with docker-compose (other options would be NixOS/Guix or using Ansible/Chef/whatever to manage hosts, but I find both less comfy than compose)
>due to mounting directories/Docker volumes for persistence, you can have everything storing data nicely in one directory that's convenient to backup, vs having software throw stuff around /etc, /var, and so on on your host
>containers behave like they're separate computers on an internal network (because they get standalone network interfaces), which makes e.g. reverse proxy configs much more readable
>Docker containers usually suggest a mindset where containers have just bare minimum to run one "app", not a whole OS inside (that's a benefit compared to LXC imo, less maintenance)
Definitely you can achieve a lot of that with Ansible, and I would even say they complement each other (with compose being imo less annoying to use to manage Docker). In my opinion docker-compose makes a lot of sense on a home server with multiple different purposes, even though it wasn't meant to do that originally. It accidentally works really well for our use cases.
You can have separate compose files btw - I split mine into software categories. Nextcloud and its shit has one YAML, torrent stuff has another, Matrix has another, Jellyfin has another, etc. A short bash function goes through them all and pulls updated images then starts them.

version: "3"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91417422
>What's the best medium for cold storage? Cheap HDD?
definately not
the best mediums for long term cold storage are, in this order:
>bluray disc - 30+ years easy
>lto tape - 30+ years in good conditions
>archival CDs/DVDs - 25-30 years
>hacking metallic vhs (miniDV is better) tape to store BLOB/TAR - 25+ years in good conditions
>regular CDs/DVDs - 20+ years in good conditions
>HDDs - 15+ years, less if SMR
>SSDs - 10-15 years maximum, decreases for every 3d layer of flash
>USB flash drives - lucky if it makes it past 5 years

>>91419421
>HBA
it's just good practice to use a dedicated SATA controller for a NAS instead of the onboard one. helps when you want to run it in a VM.
>Why get a nic? The built in one no good?
if you want to set up a firewall, you'll want more than one interface. as with the HBA, it's nice to be able to pass it through directly to the VM, in which case you'll want a 2-port NIC (LAN & WAN) and the onboard port can be a management port for the hypervisor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're worried about wifi you can physically clip the antenna with a pair of wirecutters, or just cut the entire module out. If you're worried about ethernet than you can dismantle the port with a pair of needlenose pliers. It's still possible to network over USB but you can physically glue up all the USB ports too.

We did this at work for one of our restricted machines, a computer that controls a lot of specialized pumping equipment that must always operate. The employee-facing machine is crimped off like above except for a keyboard connected over serial. It's hardwired over D-Sub into the plant-facing machine. On that the only output devices is a printer, no monitor, and the pump itself connected over D-Sub. Programs are loaded through a specialized input device requiring a physical key + tape. A 2nd person has to monitor program loading from the employee terminal to make sure it looks right, and all diagnostics are done through hex editing. When complete the system prints all reports inside the printer which is also keyed off by a separate person. If any of these devices come disconnected alarms go off.

ITT, we discuss alternative operating systems and alternative ISA.

We discuss alternatives to Windows, Mac and Linux, such as SerenityOS, Haiku, GNU/HURD, AmigaOS/AROS and rare BSDs, as well homebrew projects and operating system development.
We also we discuss non-x86 ISAs from the past (6502, 68000, Alpha, Itanium, PA-RISC, PowerPC, SuperH, VAX, Z80, PDP-11), the present (ARM, MIPS, POWER, SPARC) and the future (RISC-V, OpenPOWER).

You can also ask here for more information. Don't forget to check out the wiki, by the way!

Do you like Huey Lewis and The News?
Their early work was a little too new wave for my tastes, but when Sports came out in '83, I think they really came into their own, commercially and artistically. The whole album has a clear, crisp sound, and a new sheen of consummate professionalism that really gives the songs a big boost. He's been compared to Elvis Costello, but I think Huey has a far more bitter, cynical sense of humor.
In '87, Huey released this, Fore, their most accomplished album. I think their undisputed masterpiece is "Hip to be Square", a song so catchy, most people probably don't listen to the lyrics. But they should, because it's not just about the pleasures of conformity, and the importance of trends, it's also a personal statement about the band itself.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91397162
A couple of things I would say:
Who communicates with their doctor thru email? That's not a secure platform and from my experience in dealing with medical records data, most Dr offices are avoiding using email due to HIPAA regulations and security risks. Only talk to a medical office over the phone or in person, even if they offer communication over email. Same goes for text, nothing over SMS.
My opinion on username for personal email address, is the same system I've always recommended in this thread and others on /g/, take your initials and convert to hexadecimal. In most cases you'll have a unique 6 character alphanumeric name that no one else has already taken (unless it's Gmail which you shouldn't use to begin with).
The reason why I'm saying don't use PII in email is because even if it's just for "normie" stuff, it don't matter. You don't have control over the email once it leaves your inbox, and if someone you're communicating with gets hacked or beached, then it's out in the open that is your email much easier because it will have your full name as the handle (which is just metadata not even the data itself), and bonus retard points for people who put their birthday in the handle. Seriously, with just those data points, name and birthday, someone could easily do harm to you and even find your SSN matched to that on the dark web and start opening credit in your name. I've seen this happen before.
So in short, just don't use PII in your email or anything else online, and don't even include a name field for outgoing email.

Negative prompts won't help much with any of that. Eyes are the easiest thing to fix manually. For example I like to use close shot, portrait, head and shoulders portrait if I just want to generate a basic character design. Inpainting can fix a great deal of your problems, especially if you can draw a little yourself.

>>91424980
you have to understand how they scraped the net for training the SD models, they for one used the 5 billion picture LAION archive, which has is a gigantic scraped archive of links with text discriptions all over the net, some are from the strangest sources, so by chance, when they trained SD they might have gotten some danbooru links to, but they never added it explicitly, more went for photo archives like Getty images, stock picture archives and art museum catalogs. NAI on the did it very different, they trained explicitly on a danbooru clone (some extreme tags removed) and some other unknown archives (its all a trade secret, cause everyone wants to sue em atm) .. TL/DR: SD wants you to boomer prompt, any anime model most likely wants you to booru prompt, merges can do both

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91421383
>because it can interface directly with the UNIX operating system with no middle men
>No abstractions or APIs
This is wrong. The interface to the kernel is the asm syscall instruction. The C library is just an API and the functions are merely abstractions, they simply wrap the assembly syscall instruction. First they copy the arguments to specific registers, then they execute the syscall instruction. This causes a trap and switches the processor to kernel mode to execute the trap handler. The trap handler reads the arguments in the register to determine and call the correct kernel routine.

if you want to interface with the kernel directly without middlemen then you can't use C, it's too high level. You must use assembly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91424208
>The interface to the kernel is the asm syscall instruction.
Interface to the kernel is INT (software trap) instruction.
Linux convention is to put function number in EAX, and parameters in EBX, ECX and EDX, then call INT 80h.
INT instruction switches to supervisor mode, then jumps wherever the 80h vector points.
And it point to entry interface in the kernel.
This code then translates the code in EAX to the function address, moves parameters to the stack and does a normal CALL to that function.

C is nice for such stuff because it allows coding these kind of indirect function calls quite easily.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91425363
Not libc, KERNEL32.DLL.
On Windows libc calls KERNEL32.DLL which calls the INT trap.
You can call the INT trap yourself (the CPU does not care), but why bother if you have a nice API.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91424208
>You must use assembly.
That's where the asm keyword in C comes in.
This is why C is nice, you can write a mixture of high level code and assembly.
Also thanks to function decorators you can write shit like interrupt handlers in C without fucking up the stack or registers.
You just tell the compiler: this is an interrupt handler, please handle it like one, i.e. save/restore supervisor stack and return with IRET instead of RET.

>>91418425
>Isn't that kind of fucked, anon?
No, not really. Companies want the best people they can get. In some fields there's not many people who genuinely enjoy their work, so most companies have to settle for someone who's begrudgingly willing to do the job for enough pay. You can bet your ass that if there were enough people who genuinely loved accounting and liked to balance budgets in their spare time, then companies would start prioritizing them over people who were just barely able and willing to do the work.
And programming isn't the only field where there's enough passionate people that you can filter by them. Elementary school teachers that do informal daycare for friends or charity work for disabled children are going to be sought out above someone who doesn't really like kids or teaching but is willing to do it and put on a happy face during work hours. Most kinds of artists are expected to have portfolios including non-professional work or awards they've won from contests. A chef who never cooks for himself or his friends is less desirable. It's not particularly weird.

It's perfectly fine if you personally can't stand doing programming for both work *and* fun, but there are plenty of people who can, and those people are naturally going to gain more experience and expertise than people like you who can't. That's just reality. What do you want us to do? Force companies to ignore what people do on their own time and hire worse programmers who spend less time programming? Ban passionate programmers from programming on their own time so they can't gain an unfair advantage over dispassionate programmers who want to minimize their exposure to programming outside of work?
Your complaints are ridiculous. If you don't like the field enough to compete with everyone who does, then go do something else instead of bitching about it.

posts.com: how do C chads dive deep into the macro iceberg, and find worthwhile predefined macros to compete with C++'s metaprogramming.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91415982
All it takes is knowing one trick and lots of patience and autism.
And the name of the trick is define/include hack.
/*struct.h*/

#define FIELD(type, name) type name;

struct NAME {
  FIELDS
};
  
#undef FIELD

#define PRINT_int(value) printf("%i\n", value);
#define PRINT_float(value) printf("%f\n", value);
#define FIELD(type, name) PRINT_##type(value->name);

#define PRINTER(name) PRINTER_(name)

#define PRINTER_(name) \
void print_##name(struct name *value) { \
  FIELDS \
}

PRINTER(NAME)

#undef PRINTER

#undef FIELD
#undef PRINT_int
#undef PRINT_float

/*test.c*/
#include <stdio.h>

#define NAME test_t
#define FIELDS \
  FIELD(int, hello) \
  FIELD(float, world)

#include "struct.h"
  
int main() {
  struct test_t test = { 1, 2.0 };
  print_test_t(&test);
  return 0;
}

Here are some other links that you might find interesting
https://github.com/glouw/ctl
https://github.com/notfoundry/ppstep
https://github.com/Hirrolot/awesome-c-preprocessor
Another neat thing to note is that compilers can constant fold large macro expressions down to their values at compile time if you write them the right way. This can let you do things like functions that hash strings at compile time.

Practically, C++ just has better metaprogramming facilities with templates and constexpr (while still having macros), and some features are impossible to replicate in C with the same guarantees that C++ gives you.

From 2016-2019 I worked at a pretty big game studio doing QA. From 2020-now I've worked at a mobile game company.

Macs are not useful for actual games unless you're developing for Macs or iOS.

Developers will have PCs because that's what the majority of people play on. So you have to QC your shit.

> Game Dev
PC

> 3D Modeling
PC & Mac

> Music Production
Mac
